facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 103 of 1956. J. Umrigar and R. H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order of Madhya Bharat High Court dated February 9, 1955, in Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order of the then Madhya Bharat High Court, dated February 9, 1955, in Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954.

facts.text: Originally, the appeal was filed on behalf of the State of Madhya Bharat, now substituted by the State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Originally, the appeal was filed on behalf of the State of Madhya Bharat, now substituted by the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Ganga Ram instituted suit No. 1383 of 1952 in the court of the Additional City Civil Judge, Indore, for ejectment and arrears of rent against Revashankar.

anchor.surface_text: One Ganga Ram, stated to be the landlord of the respondent Revashankar, instituted a suit, which was numbered as 1383 of 1952 in the court of the Additional City Civil Judge, Indore, for ejectment and arrears of rent against Revashankar.

facts.text: Suit filed in name of Ganga Ram and his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai, but Chandra Mukhi Bai did not sign the plaint or vakalatnama.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated that the suit was filed in the name of Ganga Ram and his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai. It was further alleged that one Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi, a lawyer acting on behalf of Ganga Ram, advised the latter to sign the name of his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai though Chandra Mukhi Bai herself did not sign the plaint or the vakalatnama.

facts.text: On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed a complaint against five persons for offence under s.500 IPC, verified on July 13, 1953, registered as Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953 in court of Mr. N.K. Acharya, Additional District Magistrate, Indore.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed a complaint against five persons for an alleged offence under s. 500, Indian Penal Code. This complaint was verified on July 13, 1953, and was registered as Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953 in the court of one Mr. N. K. Acharya, Additional District Magistrate, Indore.

facts.text: Accused appeared on August 8, 1953, through Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

anchor.surface_text: The accused persons appeared on August 8, 1953, through Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

facts.text: On October 12, 1953, Additional District Magistrate passed order to send copies of applications and affidavits to District Judge for action against lawyers.

anchor.surface_text: on October 12, 1953, the learned Additional District Magistrate passed an order to the effect that the copies of the applications as well as of the affidavits filed by both parties should be sent to the District Judge for necessary action against the lawyers concerned.

facts.text: Criminal case No. 644 of 1953 started against Revashankar under s.497 IPC on complaint of Ganga Ram in court of Additional City Magistrate, Circle No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime a criminal case was started against Revashankar in the court of the Additional City Magistrate, Circle No. 2, for an alleged offence under s. 497, Indian Penal Code. The case was started on the complaint of Ganga Ram. That case was numbered as 644 of 1953.

facts.text: On December 17, 1953, Revashankar filed application under s.528 CrPC in court of Additional District Magistrate N.K. Acharya in Case No. 637/1953 containing serious aspersions against the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: We then come to the crucial date, namely, December 17, 1953. On that date Revashankar filed an application in the court of the Additional District Magistrate who was in seisin of Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953. The application purported to be one under s. 528, Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: First aspersion: from order dated October 12, 1953, Mr. N.K. Acharya wanted to favour Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

anchor.surface_text: The first aspersion was that from the order dated October 12, 1953 it appeared that Mr. N. K. Acharya wanted to favour Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi.

facts.text: Second aspersion: Revashankar sure he would not get impartial justice from the Magistrate based on opinions expressed.

anchor.surface_text: The second aspersion was that from certain opinions expressed by the Magistrate, Revashankar asserted that he was sure that he would not get impartial and legal justice from the Magistrate.

facts.text: Third aspersion: Magistrate had hand in conspiracy by Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi re ornaments of Chandra Mukhi Bai to involve Revashankar and brother Sushil Kumar in false theft case.

anchor.surface_text: The third aspersion was of a more serious character and it was that the Magistrate had a hand in a conspiracy hatched by Messrs. Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi regarding certain ornaments of Chandra Mukhi Bai with the object of involving, Revashankar and his brother Sushil Kumar in a false case of theft of ornaments.

facts.text: Fourth aspersion: Uma Shankar Chaturvedi paid Rs. 500 bribe to Magistrate through Ganga Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The fourth aspersion was that Mr. Uma Shankar Chaturvedi had declared that he had paid Rs. 500 to the Magistrate through Ganga Ram.

facts.text: Aspersions repeated in affidavit on December 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: These aspersions were later repeated in an affidavit on December 21, 1953.

facts.text: On January 11, 1954, Magistrate reported facts to Registrar of Madhya Bharat High Court for action against Revashankar for contempt.

anchor.surface_text: On January 11, 1954, the learned Magistrate reported the aforesaid facts to the Registrar of the Madhya Bharat High Court, and prayed for necessary action against Revashankar for contempt of court.

facts.text: High Court issued notice to Revashankar to show cause, starting Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On this report the High Court directed the issue of notice to Revashankar to show cause why action should not be taken against him under the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 and Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954 was accordingly started against Revashankar.

facts.text: Revashankar showed cause on March 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1954, Revashankar showed cause.

facts.text: High Court Division Bench of V. Newaskar and S.M. Samvatsar JJ held on February 9, 1955 that jurisdiction ousted u/s 32 Contempt Act as offence u/s 228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The case was then heard by a Division Bench consisting of V. Newaskar and S. M. Samvatsar, JJ. and by an order dated February 9, 1955, the learned Judges held that by reason of the provisions in s. 32 of the Act the jurisdiction of the High Court was ousted inasmuch as the act complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by K. Das J. on September 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is an appeal by special leave

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order and held High Court had jurisdiction to take cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the act complained of and the case must now be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.

facts.text: Magistrate denied knowing respondent or his brother and characterized aspersion as totally false.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate characterised the aspersion as totally false and said that he neither knew the respondent nor his brother and had no acquaintance with them.

facts.text: Magistrate stoutly denied aspersion of taking Rs.500 bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Another aspersion was that the Magistrate had taken a bribe of Rs. 500. This aspersion was also stoutly denied.

concepts.interpretation: No High Court shall take cognizance of a contempt alleged to have been committed in respect of a Court subordinate to it where such contempt is an offence punishable under the Indian Penal Code. Jurisdiction ousted only if contempt punishable as contempt under specific IPC provisions like ss.175,178,179,180,228, not other offences.

issues.text: whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code, and the jurisdiction of the High Court was, therefore, ousted by reason of the provision of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952

issues.text: important question with regard to the interpretation of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The appeal raises an important question with regard to the interpretation of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 XXXII of 1952 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, which repealed the earlier Contempt of Courts Act, 1926

issues.text: The question for consideration in the present appeal is if the aforesaid view of the High Court is correct

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration in the present appeal is if the aforesaid view of the High Court is correct. Mr. H. J. Umrigar, who has appeared on behalf of the appellant, has very strongly submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent complained of constituted an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, and the jurisdiction of the High Court was, therefore, ousted by reason of the provisions in s. 32 of the Act.

issues.text: whether there was any intention to insult, or whether what was said was an insult, or whether the insult was offered in any stage of a judicial proceeding

anchor.surface_text: Umrigar in reply. During the course of discussion, doubts have arisen whether there was any intention to insult, or whether what was said was an insult, or whether the insult was offered in any stage of a judicial proceeding. If any one of these three essentials is lacking, then, obviously, there is no offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed

anchor.surface_text: the public servant insulted or interrupted must be sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding. In the present case there is an initial difficulty which has been pointed out to us.

issues.text: is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted by reason of the provision in s. 32 of the Act.

arguments.claim: High Court incorrect in holding that the act constituted an offence under s.228 IPC and jurisdiction ousted u/s 32 Contempt Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole question arising for determination is whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent complained of constituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code, and the jurisdiction

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ns made against the Magistrate are of a very serious nature alleging criminal companyspiracy, and also that he had taken a bribe of Rs. 500 from the o

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court wrong; aspersions scandalise court, more than mere s.228 offence; jurisdiction not ousted per s.32 interpretation

arguments.claim: High Court relied on two SC decisions (1952 SCR 425, 1953 SCR 1169) but facts different, do not justify view

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in coming to this conclusion appears to have relied on two decisions of the Supreme Court--1952 S.C.R. 425 and 1953 S.C.R. 1169. The facts in the two Supreme Court cases were quite different and they do not, in any way justify the view taken by the High Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC relies on same precedents but distinguishes application to facts

arguments.claim: Allegations in transfer app and affidavit serious, not mere personal insult but scandalise Court, create distrust in public mind, pollute stream of justice; jurisdiction not ousted

anchor.surface_text: It will be my submission that the allegations made in the so-called transfer application as also the affidavit are of such a serious nature that they are not a mere personal insult to the Magistrate, but go far beyond they scandalise the Court in such a manner as to create distrust in the minds of the public, and pollute the stream of justice, and in such cases the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Aspersions scandalise court, impair confidence; true test is if more than mere insult

arguments.claim: No intention to insult u/s 228; in transfer app, primary object to seek transfer

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed in the High Court in reply to the show cause notice the respondent had stated that there was no intention to insult or show disrespect to the Magistrate. ... wherein it was held that where scandalous allegations were incorporated in a transfer application, there was not necessarily an intention to insult, as the primary object was to seek a transfer and not to insult the Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Intention depends on facts; in transfer apps, may be to seek transfer not insult

arguments.claim: Scandalous allegations in transfer app not necessarily s.228; High Court can punish as contempt (cites Nagpur 1941, Allahabad 1938, Patna cases)

anchor.surface_text: So far as the decisions are concerned, they support my contention that when scandalous allegations are made against a Magistrate in a transfer application they would not necessarily constitute an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and could be punished by the High Court. In L.R. 1941 Nagpur 304...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees scandalous in transfer not always s.228; cites similar Allahabad cases

arguments.claim: Allegations beyond personal insult, bring admin of justice into disrepute; jurisdiction not ousted

anchor.surface_text: I submit that where the allegations made go beyond mere personal insult and tend to bring the whole administration of justice, into disrepute, then the juris- diction of the High Court would not be ousted by s. 32 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Scandalising court impairs admin of justice

arguments.claim: Mere vulgar abuse ex facie or private life abuse = s.228; here more serious

anchor.surface_text: In a case where there is only an insult to the Judge by using vulgar abuse such as rogue or rascal and this abuse was made ex facie curiae , then it may be said that the jurisdiction of the High Court is ousted as the offence falls within the purview of s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes mere personal insult from scandalising

arguments.claim: Doubts on intention/insult/judicial proceeding ingredients of s.228; prima facie contempt anyway

anchor.surface_text: Umrigar in reply. During the course of discussion, doubts have arisen whether there was any intention to insult, or whether what was said was an insult, or whether the insult was offered in any stage of a judicial proceeding. If any one of these three essentials is lacking, then, obviously, there is no offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as the act companyplained of companystituted an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code. The question for companysideration in the pres

arguments.court_reasoning: Raises valid doubts on ingredients, esp judicial proceeding and intention

arguments.claim: Narotam Das correctly lays down law on intention

anchor.surface_text: I submit that the case relied upon by the High Court, Narotam Das v. Emperor, A. I. R. 1943 All. 97, correctly lays down the law so far as the question of intention is concerned.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites Narotam Das but qualifies tests; intention case-specific

arguments.claim: High Court view correct per SC 1952 SCR 425 & 1953 SCR 1169

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court is correct and is in accordance with the judgments of the Supreme Court in the cases reported in 1952 S.C.R. and 1953 S.C.R.

arguments.court_reasoning: Same precedents interpreted differently; apply to facts where not mere IPC offence

arguments.claim: Personal insult to magistrate = s.228 even if undermines justice; jurisdiction ousted

anchor.surface_text: If the act complained of intentionally offers a personal insult to the Magistrate concerned, it may tend to undermine the administration of justice thereby, but it will nevertheless amount to an offence under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and as such the jurisdiction of the High Court will be ousted by s. 32 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: If scandalising (more than insult), not mere s.228

arguments.claim: No two kinds of contempt; every insult punishable u/s 228

anchor.surface_text: It is unsound to say that there are two kinds of contempt, and the lesser kind of contempt will come under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and the grosser kind will not come under s. 228 every insult to a Court, whatever its nature, is contempt and punishable under s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.claim: s.480 CrPC treats s.228 as contempt punishable under IPC; jurisdiction ousted

anchor.surface_text: Section 480 of the Code of Criminal Procedure specifically mentions s. 228 of the Indian Penal Code and treats it as a form of contempt, therefore, it will be an offence of contempt punishable under the Indian Penal Code and as such the jurisdiction of the High Court would be ousted under s. 32 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eared on behalf of the appellant, has very strongl

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees s.480 shows specific IPC ss as contempt cases where jurisdiction ousted, but here more

arguments.claim: Application intended to offend/insult magistrate, attributes partiality/corruption; falls u/s 228

anchor.surface_text: Nevaskar J. said It appears to me that the application, though it was stated to be an application for transfer, was intended to offend and insult the Magistrate. A mans intention can be judged by the nature of the act he commits. The application directly and in face attributes partiality and corruption to the Magistrate.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y submitted before us that the High Court has erred in holding that the act of the respondent compan

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrong; prima facie scandalises, more than insult; doubts on intention/judicial proceeding

arguments.claim: Subordinate courts vindicate dignity under criminal law; s.32 excludes such cases

anchor.surface_text: The other learned Judge also expressed the same view... Legislature has deemed it proper to exclude such cases from the jurisdiction of the High Court under section 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.32 ouster only for contempt punishable under specific IPC ss like 228 as contempt via s.480; here scandalising not covered

arguments.claim: s.32 ouster only if contempt punishable under specific IPC provisions (via s.480 CrPC: ss.175,178,179,180,228); not other offences

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 of the Act is in these terms - No High Court shall take cognizance of a contempt alleged to have been committed in respect of a Court subordinate to it where such contempt is an offence punishable under the Indian Penal Code... excludes the jurisdiction of High Court only in cases where the acts alleged to constitute contempt of a subordinate court are punishable as contempt under specific provisions of the Indian Penal Code

arguments.claim: Object of contempt: protect public/admin of justice, not judges personally; includes scandalising court

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjea J... the object of contempt proceedings is not to afford protection to Judges personally... protection to the public... scandalising the court itself... tends to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of the people in the courts

arguments.claim: Aspersions here prima facie scandalise court, more than mere s.228 insult

anchor.surface_text: The aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of people in Courts.

arguments.claim: Uncertainty if magistrate sitting in judicial proceeding when app/affidavit filed; third ingredient of s.228 lacking

anchor.surface_text: the public servant insulted or interrupted must be sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding. In the present case there is an initial difficulty... It is not very clear from the record if the learned Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and the affidavit were filed.

arguments.claim: True test: if act is scandalising court rather than mere s.228 insult; here scandalising, jurisdiction not ousted

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then... jurisdiction... not ousted

arguments.claim: Intention u/s228 case-specific; in transfer app, may not be to insult (cites Allahabad cases)

anchor.surface_text: Whether there is an intention to offer insult to the Magistrate trying the case or not must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case... in Queen Empress v. Abdullah Khan and Emperor v. Murli Dhar... there was no intention... but the intention was merely to procure a transfer

holdings.text: The High Court was wrong in holding that the act complained of constituted an offence under s.228 IPC such that jurisdiction was ousted under s.32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the learned Judges were wrong in their view that prima facie the act complained of amounted to an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, and nothing more.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedents (Bathina Ramakrishna Reddy and Brahma Prakash Sharma), s.32 ousts jurisdiction only for contempts punishable under specific IPC provisions (ss.175,178,179,180,228 via s.480 CrPC); here aspersions scandalise court beyond mere insult.

holdings.text: Section 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 ousts High Court jurisdiction only where the contempt of a subordinate court is an offence punishable under specific provisions of the IPC such as ss.175,178,179,180,228.

anchor.surface_text: interpretation of s. 32 of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 XXXII of 1952 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, which repealed the earlier Contempt of Courts Act, 1926

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation confirmed by precedents (Ramakrishna Reddy); distinguishes acts punishable as contempt under listed IPC ss from other contempts like scandalising.

holdings.text: The true test under s.32 is whether the act is merely an offence under s.228 IPC or something more, such as scandalising the court; if scandalising, jurisdiction not ousted.

anchor.surface_text: The true test is is the act complained of an offence under s. 228, Indian Penal Code, or is it something more than that ? If in its true nature and effect, the act complained of is really scandalising the court rather than a mere insult, then it is clear that on the ratio of our decision in Ramakrishna Reddy's case the jurisdiction of the High Court is not ousted by reason of the provision in s. 32 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Develops test from precedents distinguishing mere personal insult (s.228) from acts impairing public confidence in courts (scandalising); similarity in punishment irrelevant.

holdings.text: The aspersions in the application and affidavit prima facie scandalise the court by creating distrust in the public mind and impairing confidence in courts, beyond mere personal insult under s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of people in Courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of scandalising doctrine (Brahma Prakash Sharma) to facts: allegations of conspiracy and bribery attack judicial integrity, not just personal insult.

holdings.text: Whether intention to insult under s.228 IPC exists depends on facts and circumstances of each case; no inflexible rule, particularly in transfer applications.

anchor.surface_text: Whether there is an intention to offer insult to the Magistrate trying the case or not must depend on the facts and circumstances of each case and we do not consider it necessary, nor advisable, to lay down any inflexible rule thereto.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Narotam Das; follows Allahabad precedents (Queen Empress v. Abdullah Khan, Emperor v. Murli Dhar) where transfer apps lacked insult intention.

holdings.text: It is unclear whether the Magistrate was sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding when the application and affidavit were filed, lacking third ingredient of s.228 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the public servant insulted or interrupted must be sitting in any stage of a judicial proceeding. In the present case there is an initial difficulty which has been pointed out to us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual uncertainty from record; filing practices vary, not necessarily during judicial stage.

holdings.text: The High Court had jurisdiction to take cognizance; appeal allowed, High Court order set aside, case to be decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the act complained of and the case must now be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts and law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in companying to this companyclusion appears to have relied on two decisions of the Supreme Court--1952 S.C.R. 425 and 1953 S.C.R. 1169. The facts in the two Supreme Court cases were quite different and they do number, in any way justify the view taken by the High Court.

precedents.case_name: Bathina Ramakrishna Reddy v. The State of Madras

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in companying to this companyclusion appears to have relied on two decisions of the Supreme Court--1952 S.C.R. 425 and 1953 S.C.R. 1169. We accordingly allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated February 9, 1955. In our view, the High Court had jurisdiction to take companynizance of the act companyplained of and the case must number be decided by the High Court on merits in accordance with law.
